definition: to keep an appointment/to keep one's word
to guard/to defend/to keep watch/to abide by the law/to observe (rules or ritual)/nearby/adjoining
to make an appointment/to invite/approximately/pact/treaty/to economize/to restrict/to reduce (a fraction)/concise
to weigh in a balance or on a scale

sentences.english: I managed to persuade quite a few people to see me, and I must keep the appointments.
sentences.chinese: 我好不容易說服了那麼多人和我會面，我必須守約呀。

sentences.english: People who keep appointments are considered dependable .
sentences.chinese: 守約的人被認爲是可靠的人。

sentences.english: I get asked all of the time by salespeople how to make sure that prospects keep their appointments.
sentences.chinese: 一直有銷售員問我，怎樣才能確保客戶能守約。

sentences.english: I'm very punctual. March is my sweetheart.
sentences.chinese: 我很守約，三月，是我的情郎。

sentences.english: Specify the real or implied commitment that was broken.
sentences.chinese: 詳細陳述不守約的明示的或暗示的承諾。

sentences.english: The default interest shall be allocated to the non-defaulting Parties prorata to their shareholdings.
sentences.chinese: 該違約利息由各守約方按其股權比例分配。

sentences.english: Keeping one's appointment is regarded as a virtue in many cultures.
sentences.chinese: 在許多文化中守約都是一種美德。

sentences.english: People who don't keep appointments are considered unreliable.
sentences.chinese: 不守約的人被認爲是不可信賴的。

definition: to spare no effort (idiom); to do one's utmost
to dispatch troops/to send an army/to mobilize forces
Zhang Juzheng (1525-1582), Grand Secretary during the Ming dynasty, credited with bringing the dynasty to its apogee
On learning, classic book by Confucian philosopher Xun Zi 荀子 (c. 310-237 BC)
to be content with poverty and strive for virtue (idiom)
